channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: After Lebanon Cease-Fire, Gaza and Iran’s Nuclear Ambitions Await Trump
item.description: A broader peace in the Middle East will be difficult to achieve, and Iran’s threat to Israel looms over any diplomatic effort.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A billboard depicting Iranian scientists making the Fattah-1, Iran’s first hypersonic ballistic missile, in downtown Tehran, Iran, on Tuesday.

item.title: Millions of Dollars to Protect Pandas Was Spent by China on Roads and Buildings
item.description: A Times investigation found that zoos knew conservation money went toward apartment buildings and roads. But they wanted to keep displaying pandas, so nobody looked too closely.
item.dc:creator: Mara Hvistendahl
item.media:credit: Ariana Drehsler for The New York Times
item.media:description: A female panda, Xin Bao, at the San Diego Zoo in August.

item.title: Death of Cyclist in Paris Lays Bare Divide in Mayor’s War Against Cars
item.description: Paul Varry was run over on a city street in what prosecutors suspect was a deliberate act of road rage, as bikers and drivers choose sides.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset and Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cyclists waiting for a green light on a bridge over the Seine in June.

item.title: Ukraine’s River of Anguish
item.description: Amphibious operations across the Dnipro River at Kherson illustrated the suffering and endurance of Ukrainian forces. A team of Times journalists observed the perilous movements.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall, Oleksandr Chubko and Mauricio Lima
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the 126th Territorial Defense Brigrade rested in a fortified front line position after returning from a night mission on the banks of the Dnipro River.

item.title: Chad Ends Longtime Military Partnership With France
item.description: The decision by Chad is another blow to what remained of France’s military influence in the troubled stretch of countries below the Sahara, where Russia’s influence has been growing.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: French and Chadian soldiers prepare to board a Chadian national army transport plane at Faya-Largeau airport in northern Chad in 2022.

item.title: UK Lawmakers Vote to Legalize Assisted Dying After Emotional Debate
item.description: In a landmark decision on Friday, Parliament voted in favor of allowing assisted suicide for some terminally ill people under strict conditions.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Supporters of assisted dying campaigning outside Parliament on Friday. Lawmakers voted by 330 to 275 in favor of the new legislation after a five hour debate.

item.title: Russia Moves to Cut Off Ukraine’s Nuclear Power Plants
item.description: Moscow has increasingly hit critical substations linked to nuclear power plants in an effort to disconnect them. At the same time, Ukraine replaced the commander of its ground forces.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Repairing a power line on Friday outside Odesa, Ukraine, after a Russian drone strike.

item.title: FIFA Should Compensate Migrant Workers Injured Building Qatar World Cup, Report Says
item.description: An unpublished report on the soccer governing body’s responsibility for migrant workers recommends that it should compensate those harmed.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Workers on the construction site of the Al-Wakrah Stadium, a FIFA World Cup venue, during its construction in 2018.

item.title: China Journalist, Dong Yuyu, Is Sentenced to Prison for Espionage
item.description: Dong Yuyu, who has written articles critical of the Communist Party, was arrested in 2022 while having lunch with a Japanese diplomat.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: Dong Yuyu at Harvard University in 2017. He built his career when the Chinese government encouraged interaction with foreigners, but such contacts are now viewed with extreme suspicion.

item.title: Rebels in Syria Reach Outskirts of Aleppo, in Biggest Advance in Years, Monitor Says
item.description: A new rebel assault on Syrian regime forces was closing in on the major city of Aleppo, according to rebels and a war monitor. Government warplanes struck rebel territory.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Fighters fire at Syrian government troops on the outskirts of the major city of Aleppo on Friday.

item.title: Israel Warns Residents on Both Sides of Lebanon Border to Stay Away
item.description: The cease-fire appeared to largely be holding, but it was unclear when hundreds of thousands of Lebanese and tens of thousands of Israelis could return to their homes near the border.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack and Euan Ward
item.media:description: Damage in a neighborhood of Tyre, Lebanon, as residents continued to return to their homes on Friday.

item.title: UK Transport Secretary Louise Haigh Resigns After Fraud Conviction Revealed
item.description: In the latest setback for Prime Minister Keir Starmer, Louise Haigh resigned from the cabinet Friday after admitting she pleaded guilty to a type of fraud in 2014.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Louise Haigh in London last month. As transport minister she oversaw one of the Labour Party’s flagship policies of bringing Britain’s troubled private rail network back into public ownership.

item.title: A Dublin Neighborhood at the Sharp End of Ireland’s Election Issues
item.description: In a northeast neighborhood of the capital city, deprivation and affluence exist side-by-side, and many voters feel frustrated by the status quo.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Campaign posters hanging on lamp posts and the facade of a derelict building on Sean McDermott Street in northeast inner-city Dublin, Ireland, on Nov. 27. In a recent election poll, Ireland’s three major parties, Fianna Fáil, Fine Gael and Sinn Féin, were neck-and-neck, with 21 percent, 20 percent and 19 percent, respectively.

item.title: Protests Erupt in Georgia as It Pulls Back From Pro-Western Path
item.description: Thousands of people took to the streets after the government said it had suspended talks on joining the European Union.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: The police used water cannons and tear gas to disperse anti-government protesters in front of the Parliament building in Tbilisi, Georgia, early Friday morning.

item.title: Notre-Dame Shines, and World Gets a Sneak Peek, on Macron’s Televised Tour
item.description: “You’ve achieved what was said to be impossible,” the French president told workers at the Paris monument, which will reopen after the 2019 fire.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Christophe Petit Tesson
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France during a visit to Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris on Friday.

item.title: Life After Death: America’s Cemeteries Are Rewilding
item.description: More burial sites are forgoing pristine lawns for drought resistant plants and wildflowers that help wildlife. Efforts picked up in the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley
item.media:credit: Bing Guan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn is among the earliest cemeteries in the country to be modeled after rural landscapes, and to serve as an urban park.

item.title: Here Are the Risks When Zoos Pay for Endangered Species
item.description: We tracked $86 million in U.S. money that was supposed to go toward panda conservation in China.
item.dc:creator: Mara Hvistendahl
item.media:credit: Ariana Drehsler for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yun Chuan, a male, at the San Diego Zoo in August. American zoos have come to count on pandas, which attract unparalleled crowd numbers, merchandise sales and media attention.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: The cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: Why Mexico Is Eliminating Independent Watchdog Agencies
item.description: A vote in the country’s Senate has cleared the way to abolish seven independent organizations that provided oversight on issues such as public information and price fixing.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: A protest in Mexico City last year in support of Mexico’s freedom of information body, known as INAI, after the president at the time, Andrés Manuel López Obrador, backed a proposal to scrap it.

item.title: Canada Accuses Google of Creating Advertising Tech Monopoly
item.description: The case largely echoes an antitrust action in the United States and seeks to force Google to sell off sections of its online ad business.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Canada’s competition authority said that Google owned four of the largest online advertising tech services in the country and that they control 40 percent to 90 percent of their market.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Day 2 of Lebanon’s Cease-fire
item.description: Plus, the gangs stealing hiring exams in India.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: Residents driving past a mosque in southern Lebanon, yesterday.

item.title: Lebanese Residents of Baalbek Return to a Bombed-Out City
item.description: Tens of thousands of people who had fled the city of Baalbek returned to bombed-out restaurants, flattened apartment buildings and many of the dead still buried under the rubble.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The ancient city of Baalbek, Lebanon, has been bombed and many buildings flattened.

item.title: Hiker Survives 50 Days in Canadian Wilderness
item.description: Sam Benastick was found after weeks missing in British Columbia’s frigid Redfern-Keily Provincial Park, and after the official search was called off. The police had feared “this would not be the outcome,” a spokeswoman said.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson

item.title: Romania Court Orders a Recount After Surprise Election Result
item.description: A top court issued the ruling just days after an ultranationalist outsider unexpectedly won the most votes in the first round of presidential elections held Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Matei Barbulescu and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Calin Georgescu, who won the most votes in the first round, speaking to reporters on Tuesday in Izvorani, Romania.

item.title: Daniel Khalife, UK Prison Escapee, Is Convicted of Spying for Iran
item.description: Daniel Khalife also pleaded guilty to an escape from a London jail, strapped underneath a truck with a sling made of trousers, that embarrassed the British authorities.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: A police van believed to be transporting former soldier Daniel Khalife leaving Westminster Magistrates Court in London in September 2023.

item.title: Bangladesh Ties with India Plunge Further After Arrest of Hindu Leader
item.description: India and Bangladesh have traded angry accusations about Bangladesh’s Hindu minority.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat, Anupreeta Das and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: Chinmoy Krishna Das, a Hindu leader in Bangladesh, has been accused of sedition under a colonial-era law.

item.title: What a Deadly Offensive in Syria Means for a Stalled Civil War
item.description: Rebel groups have launched the largest offensive in years against government forces in the northwest.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.category: National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.media:description: Rebel fighters in Syria’s Aleppo Province on Thursday.

item.title: What to Know About Australia’s Social Media Ban for Children Under 16
item.description: Critics say big questions remain not only about how the new law will be enforced, but also about whether the ban will really protect young people.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: The Australian government has called the legislation a “world leading” move to protect young people online.

item.title: Australia Bans Social Media for Everyone Under 16
item.description: The law sets a minimum age for users of platforms like TikTok, Instagram and X. How the restriction will be enforced online remains an open question.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: In Melbourne on Wednesday. Australia passed a social media ban for children despite feasibility concerns.

item.title: Russia Strikes Ukraine’s Energy Sector as Putin Signals More to Come
item.description: Ukraine said the attacks targeted energy infrastructure. President Vladimir V. Putin said they were retaliation for Kyiv’s use of long-range American missiles.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova, Ivan Nechepurenko and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Customers used phones as lights at a restaurant with no electricity in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Thursday after Russian strikes.

item.title: Lebanon Cease-Fire Appears to Hold Despite Israeli Strike
item.description: Israel said it had targeted militants headed to a rocket facility, but neither Israel nor Hezbollah seemed keen to immediately return to full-scale fighting.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack, Euan Ward and Aaron Boxerman

item.title: Chinese Women Mobilize Against Subpar Sanitary Pads
item.description: An online campaign has prompted major pad manufacturers to apologize. Regulators said they would consider women’s criticisms when writing new standards.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Wendy Wu/South China Morning Post, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A shelf of feminine hygiene products in a Beijing 7-Eleven convenience store.

item.title: A Top Military Official in China Is Suspended Under Suspicion of Corruption
item.description: The case of Adm. Miao Hua suggests the persistence of graft at high levels of the military, despite the efforts by Xi Jinping to stamp out corruption.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Adm. Miao Hua arriving at the Pyongyang Airport in Pyongyang, North Korea, in 2019. Until recently, he was in charge of a group that helps enforce Communist Party discipline in the military.

item.title: With Trump Returning and Hezbollah Weakened, Iran Strikes a Conciliatory Tone
item.description: As Iran faces domestic and foreign challenges, its bellicose rhetoric on the United States and Israel has given way to signs that it wants less confrontation.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A billboard in Tehran showing Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, and his predecessor, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

item.title: President João Lourenco of Angola Discusses Biden’s Upcoming Visit
item.description: President João Lourenço of Angola has worked hard to strengthen his country’s partnership with the United States and says the recent election won’t derail that.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: Joao Lourenco, the president of Angola, at the presidential palace in Luanda, Angola.

item.title: Hamas Faces a Future Without Its Most Important Ally
item.description: Israel’s offensive against Hezbollah and the cease-fire to stop the fighting in Lebanon have left Hamas increasingly isolated.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Adam Rasgon, Aaron Boxerman and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: A mosque in Gaza damaged by an Israeli airstrike. The Biden administration has tried to increase pressure on Hamas to make a deal with Israel and release the hostages it holds in Gaza.

item.title: The U.S. Is Building an Early Warning System to Detect Geoengineering
item.description: Balloon launches from around the world are part of a new kind of global alarm system: One that can detect if another country tries to dim the sun.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:credit: Tatsiana Chypsanava for The New York Times

item.title: India’s Exam Leaks Underline the Nation’s Bigger Problem
item.description: The economy has failed to create enough good jobs, so a government post appeals to far more people than there are openings, fueling desperation.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Indian police officers checking the documents of people preparing to take exams to join the police force outside the examination center in Meerut, Uttar Pradesh, in August.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: The first day of a truce between Hezbollah and Israel.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Cars moving south on a busy road near Beirut, the capital of Lebanon. There are hopes that a cease-fire agreement will end 13 months of bloodshed.

item.title: Indian Thieves See a Gold Mine in Exams for Government Jobs
item.description: In a country where government jobs are highly coveted, the tests that govern hiring are a lucrative target for criminal gangs.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Hari Kumar and Atul Loke
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times

item.title: 850-Year-Old Smithfield Meat Market in London to Close
item.description: The historic site in Britain’s capital has been a market for centuries. The local authority voted this week to close it.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Smithfield has been the site of a market since at least 1174. The current market was built in the 1860s.

item.title: As Plastic Talks Continue, a Reminder of What We’re All Exposed To
item.description: As international talks continue this week, a dozen U.N. officials reveal scientists tracked their exposure to many chemicals found in plastics.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: Scientists can use silicone wrist bands to measure a person’s exposure to chemicals.

item.title: Syrian Rebel Groups Launch Largest Offensive in Years
item.description: Scores of people were killed after forces opposed to the government of President Bashar al-Assad overtook a Syrian military base, a monitoring group reported.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:description: Clashes between fighters from Hayat Tahrir al-Sham and the Syrian Army in Aleppo on Wednesday.

item.title: E.U. Vessels Surround Anchored Chinese Ship After Cables Are Severed in Baltic Sea
item.description: Multiple countries are investigating and the authorities in Europe say they have not ruled out sabotage. But U.S. intelligence officials have assessed that the cables were not cut deliberately.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Muyi Xiao and Riley Mellen
item.media:credit: Mikkel Berg Pedersen/Ritzau Scanpix, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A bulk carrier called the Yi Peng 3 traveling under a Chinese flag was being monitored by Danish naval patrol vessels.

item.title: How Have Israel and Lebanon Responded to the Cease-Fire?
item.description: The truce began Wednesday, bringing a fragile peace to Israel and Lebanon. Israeli troops are to withdraw in phases from southern Lebanon, and Lebanese military convoys headed south to protect the peace.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: A street in Tyre, Lebanon, on Wednesday, hours into the start of the cease-fire.

item.title: As Israel-Hezbollah Cease-Fire Takes Hold, Thousands in Lebanon Head Home
item.description: The cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah began on Wednesday, but much hardship and uncertainty lie ahead after a yearlong war that killed thousands and left widespread destruction in Lebanon.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward, Ben Hubbard, Aaron Boxerman and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: People celebrating as they drove south of Beirut, Lebanon, on Wednesday.

item.title: Northern Israel Somber as a Few Soldiers and Residents Trickle Through
item.description: While there were limited signs of life in the area, most residents were hesitant to head back without greater certainty that the cease-fire with Hezbollah would hold.
item.dc:creator: Natan Odenheimer
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some Israeli troops have begun to return to Israel from Lebanon, but many remain.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: A Fragile Cease-fire in Lebanon
item.description: Plus, a post-election Thanksgiving.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of the Dahiya, south of Beirut, celebrated the cease-fire announcement yesterday.

item.title: Who Is Senior Gen. Min Aung Hlaing of Myanmar?
item.description: The country’s military leader has been accused of crimes against humanity over the army’s persecution of the Rohingya ethnic group.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Senior Gen. Min Aung Hlaing, chief of Myanmar’s military junta, at a meeting in Moscow in 2022.

item.title: Pakistan’s Capital Is Turned Upside Down by Unending Protests
item.description: Residents of Islamabad are tiring of regular demonstrations demanding the release of the former prime minister Imran Khan, with the marches leading to clashes with security forces.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:description: Supporters of Imran Khan marching toward Islamabad on Monday after clearing shipping containers placed by the authorities to block them.

item.title: Moscow Expels 2 German Journalists Over Allegations of Closing Russian TV Bureau
item.description: The German government denied it had taken action against Russia’s Channel One office in Berlin but said two Russian journalists no longer had residency permits.
item.dc:creator: Nataliya Vasilyeva and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: The logo of ARD, the German public broadcaster, on the facade of its studio in Berlin.

item.title: French Intellectuals Decry Dissident Writer Boualem Sansal’s Arrest in Algeria
item.description: An outspoken French-Algerian novelist returned to his homeland and was promptly taken into custody at age 75.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Boualem Sansal in Paris in 2015. The Algerian-born writer became a French citizen this year.

item.title: Israeli Forces Keep Striking in Gaza Alongside Cease-Fire in Lebanon
item.description: While Israel and Hezbollah were finalizing a cease-fire to halt the fighting in Lebanon, Israeli strikes killed 33 people in Gaza, according to local health authorities.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Iyad Abuheweila
item.media:description: A damaged site in Nuseirat, in central Gaza, on Wednesday after an Israeli strike.

item.title: A Battered and Diminished Hezbollah Accepts a Cease-Fire
item.description: Thirteen months of war left Hezbollah weakened, isolated and desperate for a way to stop the fighting.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of the Dahiya, south of Beirut, celebrated the announcement of a U.S.-backed cease-fire on Wednesday.

item.title: France Suggests It Would Not Immediately Arrest Netanyahu Despite I.C.C. Warrant
item.description: The Foreign Ministry did not say outright that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel would be free to travel to France, but it argued that an I.C.C. rule on immunity may apply to him.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Marlise Simons
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, left, with President Emmanuel Macron of France in Paris in 2023.

item.title: Oxford University Names William Hague Its New Chancellor
item.description: Mr. Hague, a former leader of Britain’s Conservative Party, was chosen in a vote by his fellow alumni to lead the elite university.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: William Hague at the Wimbledon tennis championships in England in July.
